original_title: Sri Lankan shares gain, boosted by financial and capital sectors
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares gained for the first time in eleven sessions on Wednesday, pushed up by financial and capital sectors, an analyst said.
“The market moved on an upward trend, bouncing back after muted sentiments,” an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index (ASPI) was up 1.02 percent, or 88.45 points, to 8,799.91.
“There were margin calls on Wednesday, as prices were down,” an analyst said.
The index dropped to 8,900 on Friday after comments made by the President regarding debt restructuring, according to an analyst.
The most liquid index, S&P SL20, was up 1.18 percent, or 29.63 points, to 2,534.03.
The market had been on muted sentiments due to fears of domestic debt restructuring, poor earnings performance, and comments by the President on the potential closure of the stock market.
In the previous session, Expolanka was losing due to earnings reports disclosing major losses of 1.2 billion rupees.

The market generated a turnover of 611 million rupees. The largest contributor to revenue was the Capital Goods Industry, contributing 197 million rupees. The total turnover was below the daily average of 1.5 billion rupees.
The market also generated a net foreign outflow of 73 million rupees. (Colombo/May03/2023)
